chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect faltering growth?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Regular growth measurements (weight and length [from birth to 2 years] or weight and height [if aged over 2 years]) should be recorded in the parent or carer-held Personal Child Health Record and plotted on the UK World Health Organization (WHO) growth charts to provide a visual representation of growth over time.

During the first few days of life:

  • If weight loss is more than 10% of birth weight or weight does not return to birth weight by 3 weeks of age — suspect faltering growth.

After the first few days of life:

  • Weight measurements — suspect faltering growth if:
    • Weight falls across 1 or more weight centile spaces and birthweight was below the 9th centile.
    • Weight falls across 2 or more weight centile spaces and birthweight was between the 9th and 91st centiles.
    • Weight falls across 3 or more weight centile spaces and birthweight was above the 91st centile.
    • Current weight is below the 2nd centile for age, regardless of birthweight.
  • Body mass index (BMI) in children over the age of 2 years — suspect faltering growth if:
    • BMI is below the 2nd centile — this may be due to undernutrition or a small build.
    • BMI is below the 0.4th centile — this suggests probable undernutrition.
  • Length or height measurements — suspect faltering growth if:
    • The child's length or height centile is more than 2 centile spaces below the mid-parental centile — this may indicate undernutrition or a primary growth disorder.
    • Instructions for calculation of the mid-parental height and use of the mid-parental centile comparator are printed on the UK WHO growth charts available from the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health (RCPCH).
  • All growth measurements should be recorded in the parent or carer-held Personal Child Health Record.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to suspect faltering growth in childhood are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence guideline Faltering Growth – recognition and management [NICE, 2017].

  • Growth in children in the UK is monitored on growth charts which combine the World Health Organization (WHO) growth standards (based on longitudinal studies of healthy breastfed infants) and UK birth and preterm growth data [Shields, 2012; NICE, 2017].
  • Further information on UK WHO growth charts is available from the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health website.
    • Specific growth charts for very preterm infants, children with significant health problems and children with Down’s syndrome are available.
